thread.title: TEMECULA: Classical duo performs a journey of sounds at The Merc
thread.title_full: TEMECULA: Classical duo performs a journey of sounds at The Merc - Press Enterprise

author: STEPHANIE SCHULTE
title: TEMECULA: Classical duo performs a journey of sounds at The Merc
text:
BY STEPHANIE SCHULTE / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 21, 2015 2:59 p.m. TEMECULA: Classical duo performs a journey of sounds at The Merc Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 2 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Classics at the Merc features pianist Paul Kenyon and violinist Päivikki Nykter. , COURTESY OF PAUL KENYON Related article » IF YOU GO When : 3 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 25.
Where : The Merc at the Old Town Temecula Community Theater, 42051 Main St., Temecula.
Admission : $12, general admission; $5, students with ID.
Information : 866-653-8696, temeculatheater.org .
This weekend's Classics at The Merc concert will not only take the audience on a sweeping and exotic journey through the sounds of piano and violin, but also on music from around the world.
Violinist Päivikki Nykter and pianist Paul Kenyon will perform a unique selection of music at Sunday, Oct. 25.
“This isn’t your grandparents’ classical music concert,” Kenyon said in phone interview.
Kenyon said the performance will begin with a Japanese piece by Toru Takemitsu.
“Most people don’t think of Japan when they think of classical music,” he said. “The song is based on an expressive poem. It’s like a Japanese love song.”
He said the song features unique violin techniques of high and low notes that add color to the sound, with Nykter utilizing the bow in unusual ways. On the piano, he said the scales and chords are not something heard in Western music.
Other songs include pieces from the Czech Republic, Estonia and will conclude with a romantic selection by German composer Richard Strauss.
Woven throughout the performance, Kenyon said he will talk to the audience and discuss the songs and the locations where the music originated.
The duo has been performing together for five years and join up when they can synchronize their busy schedules.
“We don’t do what most people consider a classical music concert,” Kenyon said.
Upcoming Classics at The Merc concerts include the Quartet Nouveau on Nov. 22.
Contact the writer: sschulte@pe.com , 951-368-9457
